title: Week 4 Homework: CodebookRepository_BrookeSarah
text: Preface

title: 1  Introduction
text:
2 Study Information
1. Assess the relationship between different factors (intensity, involvement, and technicality) and popularity of songs.
We will use spotify data from the TidyTuesday dataset.
Table 4.1 shows a sample of the variables we have added for analysis:

Summary
Test

1 + 1

[1] 2
References

title: 1  Introduction
text:
2.1 Hypotheses

2.1.1 Hypothesis 1 (Brooke):
From a factor analysis of several variables in the Spotify data, three factors emerged that describe the various components of the songs. It is hypothesized that both the intensity and involvement factors will predict song popularity such that the higher the factor score, the more likely the the song will have a higher popularity score (over and above the effects of the other factor scores). The third factor, technicality, will not significantly predict song popularity.
song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]


2.1.2 Hypothesis 2 (Sarah):
I hypothesize that song length will predict track type (song or not) but will not predict whether a song is both live and acoustic. For the relationship between track length and track type, I expect that longer tracks are less likely to be a song. I hypothesize that covariates (tempo, loudness, genre) would not affect the outcome.
p(song) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, song is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)
p(liv_acoust) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, liv_acoust is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)

title: 1  Introduction
text:
5.1 Study Design
Brooke: Part 1 of this study was based off of Brooke’s imagination rather than existing literature. The design. More details regarding the specifics of the dataset can be obtained from TidyTuesday.
Sarah: Part 2 consists of the same data as part 1. Specifics of the dataset can be found at the above address.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.1 Explanation of Existing Data
Brooke: the data has only been accessed thus far to complete a factor analysis of a subset of the existing variables of the Spotify dataset. Beyond the creation of factor scores, no summary statistics containing the outcome variable have been examined.
Sarah: Summary statistics have not been assessed on this data yet. This data has only been used to generate new variables of interest based on the existing data. The new variables are length, song, and liv_acoust.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.2 Data Collection Procedures
See the TidyTuesday webpage for a detailed description of how this data was collected and compiled.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.3 Sample Size
The sample size of Part 1 of this study is 32,833. This number was obtained based on the number of factor scores that were created.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
6.4 Sample Size Rationale
Brooke: The sample size was constrained to the existing observations in the dataset (secondary data analysis).

title: 1  Introduction
text:
7.1 Manipulated Variables
Brooke: See attached document (“Homework3.pdf”) with code and descriptions for the factor analysis that was conducted to obtain predictor variables.
Homework3.pdf
Sarah: The attached document “salas_sarah_HW3.html” describes the new variables generated in the dataset. The variable “length” is continuous and measured in minutes. The variable “song” is binary a denotes whether a track is likely a song. The variable “liv_acoust” is binary and denotes whether a track is both live and acoustic.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
7.2 Measured Variables
Brooke: The three factors have the following variables: Factor One: 1) energy, 2) loudness 3) acousticness, 4) liveness. Factor Two: 1) danceability, 2) valence, 3) speechiness, 4) tempo, 5) instrumentalness, Factor Three: 1) mode, 2) key.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.1 Statistical models
Brooke: I will use a model comparison approach to test the following model: song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]
Sarah: I will use logistic regression with nested models to assess two relationships (1) the relationship between track length and being a song and (2) the relationship between track length and being both live and acoustic. For 1 and 2, I will run models with just the main variables of interest then run new models with the added covariates.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.2 Transformations
Brooke: Please see Homework 3 attachment for a detailed description of the conducted transformations (i.e., factor scores). No other transformations will be conducted in this dataset.
Sarah: There are no transformations expected for this analysis

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.3 Missing data
Brooke: For the purposes of this project, I will just drop any observations (songs) that do not have factor scores.
Sarah: Should there be missing observations for the variables of interest, these will not be included in the analysis. Large amounts of missing data will be assessed for any systemic patterns.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
8.4 Exploratory Analysis
Brooke: The only exploratory analysis that was or will be conducted was factor analysis, which was described in the Homework 3 attachment.
Sarah: Exploratory analysis will examine any correlations between the measures for song, live, and acoustic along with length. Correlations will also be found between the two outcome variables and tempo and loudness.




Tabachnick, Barbara G., Linda S. Fidell, and Jodie B. Ullman. 2019. Using Multivariate Statistics. Seventh edition. NY, NY: Pearson.

title: 2  Chapter 2
text:
2.1 Brooke
Description of factors
The three factors have the following variables:
Factor One: 1) energy, 2) loudness 3) acousticness, 4) liveness.
Factor Two: 1) danceability, 2) valence, 3) speechiness, 4) tempo, 5) instrumentalness,
Factor Three: 1) mode, 2) key.
From this, I’m going to give the factors different names that are more descriptive than PA1-PA3. Factor One seems to describe the intensity of a song and a measurable amount of property, so I’ll rename Factor One to pa1_intensity (pa = principal axis and 1 = originally factor 1). Factor Two seems to describe level of involvement, which may be a little bit of a stretch, but involvement meaning the extent to which singers, instruments, and movement (i.e., dancing) contribute to a song. I’ll rename Factor Two to pa2_involvement. Finally, Factor Three is pretty basic and describe very technical aspects of songs, so I’ll rename Factor Three to pa3_technicality.

title: 2  Chapter 2
text:
2.2 Sarah

title: 3  Chapter 3
text:
3.2 Background

3.2.1 Loading packages

library(tidyverse)
library(psych)
library(GPArotation)
library(psy)
library(plotrix)
library(FactoMineR)



3.2.2 Loading spotify data

d <- tidytuesdayR::tt_load('2020-01-21')$spotify_songs


    Downloading file 1 of 1: `spotify_songs.csv`

names(d)

 [1] "track_id"                 "track_name"              
 [3] "track_artist"             "track_popularity"        
 [5] "track_album_id"           "track_album_name"        
 [7] "track_album_release_date" "playlist_name"

[11] "playlist_subgenre"        "danceability"            
[13] "energy"                   "key"                     
[15] "loudness"                 "mode"                    
[17] "speechiness"              "acousticness"            
[19] "instrumentalness"         "liveness"                
[21] "valence"                  "tempo"                   
[23] "duration_ms"             




3.2.3 New variables using Spotify data
When thinking about creating three new variables from this Spotify data, I’m curious to know whether there are any latent factors within them. I’m going to run an exploratory factor analysis (EFA) to find out, and then create factor scores based on the latent dimensions that I find.

3.2.3.1 Correlation matrix
Before running the EFA, first I’ll look at a correlation matrix to see whether any of the variables have reasonable correlations.

cor_matrix <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo, duration_ms) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

cor_matrix %>% 
  round(2) %>% 
  knitr::kable()

Looking at the correlation matrix, it seems that loudness and energy are highly positively correlated (r = .68), valence and danceability are positively correlated (r = .33), acousticness and energy are negatively correlated (r = -.54), and acousticness and loudness are negatively correlated (r = -.36). There are a few other smaller correlations, but these are the main ones. I wonder if there could be two factors that relate to how upbeat or chill a song is.
In terms of outliers, it looks like duration in ms, mode, and key aren’t really correlated with much, but mode and key are correlated with each other. I think I’m going to eliminate duration in ms because I’m not sure that relates a ton to the other variables. I’ll keep mode and key! (Also I’m aware this is pretty arbitrary but I’m just going with it haha)

# removing the outlier (duration_ms) from the correlation matrix
cor_matrix2 <- d %>% 
  select(danceability, energy, key, loudness, mode, speechiness, acousticness, instrumentalness, liveness, valence, tempo) %>% 
  cor(use = "pairwise.complete.obs")

title: 3  Chapter 3
text:
3.3 Sarah
I created three new variables in this data. Table 1 shows the new variables created from the existing Spotify data which includes song length (in minutes), whether the track is a song, and whether the track is both live and acoustic.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
3.1 Our hypotheses are:

3.1.1 Hypothesis 1 (Brooke):
From a factor analysis of several variables in the Spotify data, three factors emerged that describe the various components of the songs. It is hypothesized that both the intensity and involvement factors will predict song popularity such that the higher the factor score, the more likely the the song will have a higher popularity score (over and above the effects of the other factor scores). The third factor, technicality, will not significantly predict song popularity.
song_popularity = b0 + b1_intensity + b2_involvement + b3_technicality [all predictors are continuous]


3.1.2 Hypothesis 2 (Sarah):
I hypothesize that song length will predict track type (song or not) but will not predict whether a song is both live and acoustic. For the relationship between track length and track type, I expect that longer tracks are less likely to be a song. I hypothesize that covariates (tempo, loudness, genre) would not affect the outcome.
p(song) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, song is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)
p(liv_acoust) = b0 + b1_length (+ b2_tempo + b3_loudness + b4_genre) (where genre is categorical, liv_acoust is binary, and the rest of the variables in the model are continuous)

text:

title: 1  Introduction
text:
We seek to explore various aspects of song data taken from Spotify. The data is available through TidyTuesday, found here.
The TidyTuesday project aims to help those learning R use the software in real-world applications. We use the available data to answer two major questions. We seek to find predictors of song popularity as well as those for track type (song or otherwise) and whether a track is both live and acoustic.

title: Final Paper
text: Brooke’s results go here

title: 4  Results 2
text:
Results of the analysis are shown below. Table 4.1 shows the results of the logistic regressions estimating the likelihood of a track being a song. Table 4.2 shows the results of the same estimate but with the added covariates genre (as a factor variable), tempo, and loudness.
The results of the first model (Table 4.1) indicates that a longer track length is associated with a 2.6936147 higher likelihood of being a song. When we add in the other covariates (Model 2, Table 4.2), the likelihood of a track being a song is 1.6704087 times higher when a track is 1 minute longer.
The results of Models 3 and 4 (Table 4.3 and Table 4.4) show us that track length do not determine the combined liveness and acoustiness of a track. The results for both models were not significant.

title: Final Paper
text: Discussion will go here

title: 2  Data and Methods
text:
2.2 Methods
[Brooke]
The second portion of our analysis comprises nested logistic regressions. The first model estimates the likelihood that a track is a song with track length as the predictor. The second model estimates the likelihood that a track is both live and acoustic with the same main predictor. Models 3 and 4 mirror models 1 and 2 but include the covariates tempo, loundess, and genre. Results are presented in odds ratios.
